description: Perhaps from prin (“twig, shoot”), variant of prene (“spike, nail”), from Old English preon, from Proto-Germanic *preunaz (“knitting needle”).

entries.meaning: A cone-shaped spool or bobbin on which thread or yarn is wound, used most often for weaving.
The amount of thread wound on a shuttle or reel.

verbs.description: pirn (third-person singular simple present pirns, present participle pirning, simple past and past participle pirned)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To wind (yarn) onto a pirn, usually by means of a pirn winder.
